content: docs#IsClosed.isGδ is stated for a uniform space with countably generated uniformity. This is true more generally for a docs#PerfectlyNormalSpace. I'm thinking of generalizing this to perfectly normal spaces and nearby docs#IsGδ.setOf_continuousAt for pseudometrizable spaces, but I wanted to see what others think of this first.
I don’t understand what you mean. It’s not really “true more generally” for perfectly normal space since it’s simply part of the definition.

I think IsClosed.isGδ should be the preferred spelling of PerfectlyNormalSpace.isClosed_gdelta, and that typeclass inference should find UniformSpace X + (uniformity X).IsCountablyGenerated -> PerfectlyNormalSpace X. Does that make more sense?
It makes a bit more sense, but I would need to see a more detailed plan and think a bit about it. It’s almost midnight here so I don’t see immediately how you would get that the space is normal.
For instance, can you get that the space is separable under those assumptions alone?
You can get Normal and Closed Sets Gδ from a pseudometric, and we have docs#UniformSpace.pseudoMetrizableSpace
First reference I can think of is pi-base.

Ok, then you can try to add those instance and see whether it breaks anything. Don’t forget to test performance across Mathlib if you PR that, especially if you don’t have an application in mind. Sometimes changing the type class synthesis paths can make things slower, so we don’t always aim for the most general instances when there are no applications. I’m writing this specifically because reading pi-base very much encourages working on general topology with no application in mind.
Right now we have no instances for T6Space, and the only instance for PerfectlyNormalSpace is the one coming from T6Space, so part of it is that I want to show that metric spaces are T6.

Patrick Massot said:

Don’t forget to test performance across Mathlib if you PR that, especially if you don’t have an application in mind.

How do I do that?
If you add the label bench-after-CI, once the PR passes CI, it will trigger a benchmarking.
(And you can trigger a manual benchmarking by commenting !bench on a PR.)
